results.title: Human beginnings
results.creator_credit: Eddie Albert Productions and University of Oregon
results.brief_description: The film opens showing a class of six-year-old boys and girls working out, through drawing and clay models, their ideas of how a baby grows inside its mother. Each child holds up their drawing and explains to the others what it means to them. The film indicates that all the children have a sound basic idea about human growth and the value of discussion with caring adults.

results.title: Human aggression (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Follows the activities of a youth gang, showing how aggression is used to assert dominance and territoriality; is provoked by frustration; and is displaced onto others. The frustration-aggression hypothesis is discussed and demonstrated in a laboratory experiment. Modifications to the hypothesis point to frustration as a key element in provoking aggression. Considers the importance of the psychological training of police who intervene in aggressive disputes.

results.title: The Hula fishermen and Koki market
results.creator_credit: Information and Extension Services for the people of Papua New Guinea
results.brief_description: Shows the daily work of men of the Hula tribe, who net and spear fish for marketing at Koki, Port Moresby. The market is shown as a social meeting place of varied Papuan peoples.

results.title: How's it going?
results.brief_description: The four cases that make up this film deal with an important management activity: the interview. They have been designed to permit investigation of basic interviewing principles and techniques for appraising employee performance. Specifically, they serve as a springboard for analysing four goals of both interviewer and interviewee: understanding, agreement, action and learning. Methods for dealing with interview problems. The four cases are: 1. More than paperwork. 2. Give and take. 3. Means to an end. 4. The way ahead.

results.title: How will we know it's us?
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Ravitz, Lawrence Ravitz Associates and National Trust for Historic Preservation
results.brief_description: Explores the importance of preserving and restoring historic buildings, explaining that continuity and change need not fight each other. We see projects in five communities throughout America in which preservation has been an essential element in urban renewal programs.

results.title: How we get our power
results.brief_description: Explains how power comes from nature and how humans have learned to put this power to use. Surveys the major sources of power: wind, water, fuel, explosives and the atom.

results.title: How vacuum tubes work
results.creator_credit: Peter Robinson, Leonard Bender and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description: Explains the structure of a diode and a triode and how they work as a rectifier and amplifier. Illustrates clearly why the hot filament and cold plate will permit the plate current to flow in one direction only and this functions as a half-wave rectifier.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Robinson, Leonard Bender and McGraw-Hill Films
